title: Default tax rates
body: The portfolio tax country this default tax rate is used for.

title: Default tax rates
body: Security type

title: Default tax rates
body: The security type this default tax rate is used for (if no security type is chosen, the default tax type is used for all types of securities when other conditions are met).

title: Default tax rates
body: Security subtype

title: Default tax rates
body: The security's subtype this default tax rate is used for (if no security subtype is chosen, the default tax type is used for all types of securities when other conditions are met).

title: Default tax rates
body: Tax rate

title: Default tax rates
body: Define the tax rate used by default for the combination of the criteria selected from the previous fields.

title: Default tax rates
body: Tax type

title: Default tax rates
body: Define the tax type, defined in Preference - Tax types, of the default tax rate.

title: Default tax rates
body: The default tax rate is saved with the OK button below the fields.

title: Tax types
body: Tax types are used for determining the type of a tax recorded to a transaction: the transaction window has two fields for recording a tax to the transaction, and the tax types defined in preferences can used to identify and categorize these taxes recorded to transactions. Tax types are also used in defining default tax rates for running corporate actions. For example, a tax type can be capital gains tax or VAT.

title: Tax types
body: Tax types can be defined in the Tax types window in Preference. The existing tax types are listed on the left-hand side of the window. The tax types can be viewed and modified by choosing them from the listing. The Delete button deletes the chosen tax type and the OK button saves the changes made.

title: Tax types
body: A new tax type is added with the Add tax type button. The tax type information is defined in the fields on the right-hand side of the window. A red star indicates that a field is mandatory.

title: Tax types
body: Code*

title: Tax types
body: The individual tax type code that separates it from other tax types.

title: Tax types
body: Name*

title: Tax types
body: The name of the tax type. The name of the tax type is shown in the Transaction window.

title: Tax types
body: Profit

title: Tax types
body: The selection tells whether the tax type has a profit effect. The profit effect indicates whether the amount of this type of tax will have an effect on the portfolio's profit and whether the amount of this type of tax will be included in the position's purchase value. By default, the profit effect is not selected, and the tax will not have an effect on the portfolio's profit or will not be included in the portfolio's purchase value.

title: Tax types
body: Cash

title: Tax types
body: The selection tells whether the tax type has a cash effect. The cash effect determines whether this type of tax has an effect on the portfolio's cash, i.e. is the amount of the tax deposited to or withdrawn from the portfolio's account with the transaction. By default, the cash effect is selected, and the tax has the same effect on the portfolio's account as the transaction does. If not selected, only the net price of the transaction without the tax of this type would affect the portfolio's cash.

title: Tax types
body: The tax type is saved with the OK button below the fields.

title: Preference - Transactions
body: Transaction preferences allow you to set the options available in the fields when defining the information of a transaction in the Transaction window. Transaction type preferences allow you to control how your transactions affect your portfolio's contents.

title: Transaction cost types
body: Transaction cost types preferences allow you to define the cost types available for transactions. The cost types are used to categorize the costs and fees recorded to transactions: for example, transaction cost types can include advisory fees, custodian fees or broker commissions.

title: Transaction cost types
body: Transaction cost types can be defined in the Transaction cost types window in Preference. A cost type consists of a name and a type: the name is used to view and choose the type in the user interface and the type is used to identify the cost type.

title: Transaction cost types
body: In addition, you can categorize your transaction cost types, allowing you to associate a category to each of your transaction cost types. You can categorize your transaction cost types as Portfolio (investment service costs), Security (product costs) or 3rd (third party payments), and then further as Not categorized (default), One-off charges, On-going charges, Charges related to transactions, Charges related to ancillary services or Incidental charges, or from up to five additional Other cost categories. The cost category of a transaction cost type is utilized in ex-post cost analysis: when a category is set to a transaction cost type, the amount of the cost is summed into the selected cost category. For example, you can categorize the brokerage fees you record on your transactions as Charges related to transactions., when the amount of brokerage fee you enter into your transaction is considered as charges related to transactions in ex-post cost reporting.

title: Transaction types
body: Transaction type preferences allow you to see the transaction types available in the system together with the characteristics and effects of the defined transaction types. Transaction types are relevant when creating transactions: the transaction type selected for a transaction determines what kind of combination of effects the transaction has on the portfolio.

title: Transaction types
body: For example, a transaction type "Sell" has a positive cash effect (e.g. money is deposited to portfolio's account with the transaction), negative amount and FIFO effects (e.g. a sell reduces the amount of the security in the portfolio), a sell would realize profits or losses and finally, taxes and costs reduce the trade amount of a sell (e.g. when there is a cost recorded to a sale of a security, the cost is deducted from the original trade amount and reduces the money you will actually get from the sell).

title: Transaction types
body: Do not modify the standard transaction types' effects - instead, create a new transaction type and use one of the existing types as an example. Transaction type effects often work as a combination, and changing one and not the other might not have a desirable outcome - avoid making your own combinations.

title: Transaction types
body: Transaction types are defined with the basic information of the transaction type (code and name) and through relevant effects for each transaction type. When creating a new transaction type, the effects are by default No effect or similar.

title: Transaction types
body: Type code*

title: Transaction types
body: Unique transaction type code that separates it from other transaction types.

title: Transaction types
body: Short name*

title: Transaction types
body: Short name for the transaction type, which is used in the reports as the abbreviation of the transaction type. Transaction's short name can be translated into different languages, while the transaction type's type code is used to identify the transaction types within the system and cannot be translated.

title: Transaction types
body: Name*

title: Transaction types
body: Name of the transaction type.

title: Transaction types
body: Cash effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Adds cash, or Reduces cash. The cash effect describes the effect the transaction has on the cash balance of the account linked to the transaction. For example, a "Buy" transaction reduces cash, and a "Sell" adds cash in the portfolio's account by the trade amount of the transaction.

title: Transaction types
body: Net effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Add or Reduce. The net effect affects the transaction's net cash flow to the portfolio. If there is no net cash flow on the transaction, then any effect the transaction has on the market value of the portfolio will affect the portfolio's performance (TWR). The net effect would counter these effects otherwise. The net effect works differently depending on the transaction type's cash effect: when the transaction doesn't have a cash effect, then the net cash flow is directly dependent on the net effect and the transaction's trade amount (for example, "Add" transaction type has the net effect "add" => positive net cash flow, and "Remove" transaction type has the net effect "reduce" => negative net cash flow). However, if the transaction also has a cash effect, the net cash flow of the transaction is the combination of the cash and net effects: "add" cash and net effects => positive net cash flow; "add" cash but "reduce" net effect => negative net cash flow; "reduce" cash but "add" net effect => negative net cash flow; "reduce" cash and net effects => positive net cash flow. For example, "Withdrawal" transaction type has the cash effect of "reduce" and the net effect "add", which results in a negative net cash flow effect.

title: Transaction types
body: Amount effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Adds amount, or Reduces amount. The amount effect describes the effect of the transaction's amount (i.e. units) on the amount of the security in the portfolio. For example, a "Buy" transaction adds the amount, and a "Sell" reduces the amount of a position by the amount of the transaction.

title: Transaction types
body: FIFO

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Add, Reduce, or Reduce all. FIFO describes whether the FIFO valuation method is taken into account. "No effect" means that the valuation method is not taken into account. "Add" means that the transaction is "in" and adds the amount of the security. "Reduce" means that the transaction is "out" and reduces the amount of the security. "Reduce all" means that the transaction is "out" and reduces the amount of each purchase lot proportionally.

title: Transaction types
body: Return effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Adds return (profit) or Reduces return (cost). The return effect describes the effect of the transaction on the portfolio return. For example, a "Dividend" transaction adds return. From FA 3.9 onward, the return effect determines whether a transaction is a profit (adds return) or a cost (reduces return). This allows you to explicitly control "Other profits" and "Other costs" in TWR calculation. For example, a "Dividend" transaction adds return and is considered as "Other profits". In addition, you can control for example where you want to see the effect of kickbacks - even with positive cashflow, you can configure your kickbacks to reduce return (a cost), when kickbacks would increase your (negative) costs instead of reducing your (positive) returns.

title: Transaction types
body: Realized profit effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Realize profits/losses, Realize profits/losses by closing open positions, or Realize profit indirectly. The profit effect defines, whether the transaction realizes profits - Realize profits/losses calculates realized profits from the transaction, such as sell, and shows it as “realized profit” and as “capital gain” for taxation purposes, while Realize profits/losses indirectly calculates realized profits from the transaction, and shows it only as “realized profit” but not as "capital gain". For example, a "Sell" transaction realizes profits (shown as realized profits from the performance point of view and as capital gains for taxation purposes), while a "Remove" transaction realizes profits indirectly (shown as realized profit from the performance point of view but not as capital gains on tax reports). From FA 3.9 onward, the effect "Realize profits/losses" works on its own, independent of other effects. This allows you to realize profits also when your position’s units don’t change, not only when buying or selling.

title: Transaction types
body: Purchase price effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose the purchase price effect from the alternatives. Purchase price effect allows you to adjust your position's purchase price directly with your transaction's trade amount, even when your transaction doesn't have an amount effect. For example, transactions such as "capital return", "value adjustments" at year-end, and "mark-to-market" for futures' handling often have a purchase price effect, only affecting your position's purchase value. For example "buy" and "sell" transactions don't have a separate purchase price effect since they affect the position through the amount effect.

title: Transaction types
body: "No effect" - transaction's trade amount has no direct effect on the purchase price of the position.

title: Transaction types
body: "Add", "Add, record orig values", "Add in security currency", "Add in security currency, record orig values", "Add and set fx" and "Add and set fx, record orig values" - transaction's trade amount adds the position's trade amount in different ways. These options allow you to manage "value adjustments" at year-end for bookkeeping or "mark-to-market" on your futures' positions even for non-portfolio currency securities.

title: Transaction types
body: "Reduce", "Reduce, record orig values", "Reduce in security currency", "Reduce in security currency, record orig values", "Reduce and set fx" and "Reduce and set fx, record orig values" -transaction's trade amount reduces the position's trade amount in different ways. These options allow you to manage "capital returns", "value adjustments" at year-end for bookkeeping or "mark-to-market" on your futures' positions even for non-portfolio currency securities.

title: Transaction types
body: "Keep original purchase price", "Keep original purchase time" and "Keep original purchase price and time" - allow you to keep your position's original purchase times and values when changing a position to another. These allow you to maintain your FIFO chain and values for example for "exchanges" (keep original purchase time) or "subscriptions" when the new shares' purchase value is combined with existing lots (keep original purchase price).

title: Transaction types
body: Purchase price profit effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect, Unrealized profit, or Realizes negative purchase lots. Only available when transaction type has a “Purchase unit price effect”. Controls whether adding or reducing purchase price affects unrealized profits. This allows you to control TWR calculation: Value adjustments for accounting purposes don't change “original” purchase value and thus don’t affect TWR, while capital returns change purchase value from TWR’s point of view. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Transaction types
body: No effect - purchase value is changed, but the “original” trade amount is not changed. Therefore, the unrealized profits in TWR are not affected.

title: Transaction types
body: Unrealized profit - also the “original trade amount” is affected and therefore the unrealized profits as well. In addition, if there is a difference in FX rates, which is possible if adding/reducing purchase value is done "in security currency" or with "set FX", the difference due to the FX rates is booked separately as "Realized FX profit".

title: Transaction types
body: Realizes negative purchase lots - same as the previous, but if purchase value is reduced with any of the "Reduce" effects AND the purchase value on a purchase lot would go negative, the negative part is recorded as realized profit. This effect is only used for “Capital return” transactions in Finland.

title: Transaction types
body: Unrealized profit via cost - affects the "original trade amount" of the buy transaction to which the cost is linked. Used, for example, for a legal fee that is added as a separate transaction ("Transaction cost" transaction type). The fee transaction must have the same Amount as the Buy transaction (to create a link between these tranasactions). The fee's Trade amount is added to the "original trade amount" of the buy transaction.

title: Transaction types
body: Market price effect

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from No effect, Adds market value, or Reduces market value. Market price effect allows you to adjust your position's market value directly with your transaction's trade amount. This is useful if you don't get daily market prices on your securities, and want to instead adjust the market value of your position directly with transactions, for example for "Private Equity" and "real estate" investments. If you feed market prices for your security, transactions with market price effect have no effect on your position.

title: Transaction types
body: Cost category group

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose a cost category group for your transaction from Portfolio (investment service costs), Security (product costs) or 3rd (third party payments). Within each group, select a further cost category from the next field.

title: Transaction types
body: Cost category

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose a cost category for your transaction from Not categorized (default), One-off charges, On-going charges, Charges related to transactions, Charges related to ancillary services or Incidental charges, or from up to five additional Other cost categories. The cost category of a cost transaction is utilized in ex-post cost analysis: when a category is set to a cost transaction, the trade amount of such a transaction is summed into the selected cost category. For example, you can categorize your asset management fees as Ongoing charges, when the trade amount of your asset management fee transaction is considered as ongoing charges in ex-post cost reporting.

title: Transaction types
body: Date effect

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from Effect on position on transaction date to Effect on position on settlement date. The date effect allows you to decide whether your transaction affects your portfolio's positions on the defined effective transaction date (booked date if defined, otherwise transaction date) or on the defined settlement date. By default, transactions have an effect on position on transaction date, but changing the effect on position on settlement date is especially useful for example when the effect of a deposit or withdrawal should not be shown on your bank account before the settlement date, allowing you to directly track the settled, actual available cash within your portfolio. If you configure your transactions to take effect on the settlement date, the transaction will affect all calculations, including positions, profits, and other analyses, only from the settlement date onward.

title: Transaction types
body: Ratio effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose from No effect or Relative effect on amount and unit price. The ratio effect defines whether the Ratio field of the Transaction window is available (no effect -> field not in use), and what kind of an effect the value in the field has on the security's amount and unit price.

title: Transaction types
body: Security 2

title: Transaction types
body: Security 2 defines if the transaction type has another security in addition to the security chosen in the transaction. Second security is involved, for example, in case of exchange transactions or call and put option transactions.

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose from the following options:

title: Transaction types
body: “None” – The transaction doesn’t have a second security.

title: Transaction types
body: “Removes 2nd security” - The second security units are removed from the portfolio, starting from the older purchase lots. The number of removed units is based on the transaction ratio. If the second security is not removed entirely, the remaining purchase lots are left untouched. This effect is used in exchange transactions. For example, if you have 3 units and exchange them with a ratio of 2 to 1, you will get one new unit, and one old unit is left in your portfolio.

title: Transaction types
body: “Removes 2nd security entirely” - All second security units are removed from the portfolio. For example, if you have 3 units and exchange them with a ratio of 2 to 1, you will get one new unit, and one remaining old unit is rounded away so that all old units are removed.

title: Transaction types
body: "Removes 2nd security and transfer cost" - All second security units are removed from the portfolio. All the costs and cashflows are transferred to the underlying security. The effect is used for exercising the call and put option with the EXCC and EXCP transactions. This effect makes sure that the underlying cash flows and purchase value is considered correctly i.e. canceling out the cashflows when exercised.

title: Transaction types
body: “Based on another security” - Transaction involves another security, and the transaction effects determine how it is what the effect is. For example, issues are based on your ownership of the second security.

title: Transaction types
body: “Based on another security, transfer return” – Transaction has a second security. This effect keeps the old position in the portfolio and reduces the purchase price of the old position by the equivalent of the trade amount in the transaction. For the transaction date, the market value is split between the old and new positions with the same percentage share as the purchase value was transferred. This effect makes sure that the analytics values (Market value, TWR, cashflows) are preserved in spin-offs, where the removed security is first exchanged to a "temporary security" and the temporary security is exchanged back to the original security with a new exchange corporate action.

title: Transaction types
body: Group

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose No, Yes - same, or Yes - opposite. Grouping defines, whether the transactions of the transaction type are grouped to a separate position, and do the transactions affect the same or opposite position.

title: Transaction types
body: Tax effect

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose No effect, Adds trade amount, or Reduces trade amount. The tax effect relates to the upper tax field in the Transaction window (tax from trade amount). The tax effect describes the effect of the tax on the final trade amount.

title: Transaction types
body: Tax effect 2

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose No effect, Adds trade amount, or Reduces trade amount. The tax 2 effect relates to the lower tax field in the Transaction window (tax from fees). The tax effect describes the effect of the tax on the final trade amount.

title: Transaction types
body: Cost effect 1

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose No effect, Adds trade amount, or Reduces trade amount. The cost effect describes the effect of the cost on the final trade amount.

title: Transaction types
body: Cost effect 2

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose No effect, Adds trade amount, or Reduces trade amount. The cost effect describes the effect of the cost on the final trade amount.

title: Transaction types
body: Paid in capital effect

title: Transaction types
body: Choose No effect, Adds paid in capital, or Reduces paid in capital. Defines how the transaction affects paid-in capital value visible in Analytics+. The paid-in capital is calculated based on transactions trade amount excluding taxes. If the commitment type is “amount”, the paid-in capital is calculated based on the transaction’s amount. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Transaction types
body: Commitment effect

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose No effect, Adds commitment, or Reduces commitment. Defines how the transaction affects the total commitment of a position. The remaining commitment is then determined by subtracting paid in capital from the total commitment. For example, private equity transaction type "PE - Commit" increases commitment to a position.

title: Transaction types
body: Commitment type

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose Not defined, Price, or Amount. Defines whether the commitment is calculated based on transaction's amount (i.e. units) or price (i.e. amount x unit price). Mandatory to be selected (Price or Amount) if the transaction has a "Commitment effect". (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Transaction types
body: Distribution effect

title: Transaction types
body: Сhoose No effect, Adds distribution, or Reduces distribution. Defines how the transaction affects distribution visible in Analytics+. The distribution is calculated based on transactions trade amount excluding taxes. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Transaction types
body: The following buttons are available at the bottom of Preference:

title: Transaction types
body: Translate

title: Transaction types
body: Opens the Translations window for translating the transaction type, allowing you to save translations for the transaction type to be used in reports and the user interface when a language other than the language of the transaction type is chosen.

title: Transaction types
body: Update

title: Transaction types
body: Updates the changes made to the transaction type to all the transactions of the updated type. The trade amounts and cash flows of the transactions in all portfolios are re-calculated to take into account the changes made to transaction types, and the affected reports are re-calculated.

title: Transaction types
body: Versions

title: Transaction types
body: Opens the Versions window to allow you to follow the changes made to the information.

title: Transaction types
body: Clicks of the "Update" button are audited - user audit tracks user clicks on transaction type updates that might lead to report recalculation. Every time a user clicks Update in the Transaction type preferences, the user audit contains the message ”User [username] clicked Update in Preference/Preference”. Also, every time a report recalculation is started, the system audit logs which portfolios' reports are recalculated and from which date onward. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: Transactions
body: Transactions preferences allow you to enable the Transaction window to ask for confirmation messages and to set the settlement date automatically. You can also define the default purchase price (original or transaction) to be used on the reports, and the trade order statuses available for your trade order flow:

title: Transactions
body: Confirmation if the balance of the account is less than the total value of the transaction / Confirmation if the amount of the security in the portfolio is less than the amount defined in the transaction

title: Transactions
body: By default, neither of these confirmation messages is enabled: you can set the system to ask one or both of the confirmation messages from the check box. The purpose of these confirmation messages is to make sure that a transaction does not by mistake make the account balance or the amount of the security in the portfolio negative. When a transaction is saved, the system confirms the action with a Yes/No pop-up window, if the total value of the transaction exceeds the account balance, or the amount of a security exceeds the amount of the security in the portfolio.

title: Transactions
body: Set the transaction's settlement date automatically based on the transaction date

title: Transactions
body: Enable or disable setting the settlement date automatically. When enabled, whenever you enter a transaction date, the settlement date is automatically set a certain number of business days from the transaction date.

title: Transactions
body: Amount of business days to add to the transaction's settlement date

title: Transactions
body: Define how many business days ahead the settlement date is set from the transaction date. You can override this on the security level: if the "Enable settlement date" has been enabled for the transaction's security (or cash transaction's currency's), the number of days defined in "Settlement date" is used to calculate the settlement date for trades in that security. In addition to how many business days trades take to settle, the transaction's security's (or cash transaction's currency's) holiday calendar is used to determine which days are business days.

title: Transactions
body: Set the trade order's settlement date automatically based on the transaction date

title: Transactions
body: Enable or disable setting the settlement date automatically. When enabled, whenever you enter a transaction date, the settlement date is automatically set a certain number of business days from the transaction date.

title: Transactions
body: Amount of business days to add to trade order's settlement date

title: Transactions
body: Define, how many business days ahead the settlement date is set from the transaction date. You can override this on the security level: if the "Enable settlement date" has been enabled for the transaction's security (or cash transaction's currency's), the number of days defined in "Settlement date" is used to calculate the settlement date for trades in that security. In addition to how many business days trades take to settle, the transaction's security's (or cash transaction's currency's) holiday calendar is used to determine which days are business days.

title: Transactions
body: Use original purchase value in portfolio reports by default

title: Transactions
body: By enabling this setting, the original purchase value is used in the portfolio reports by default for transactions with original transaction information defined. By default, this setting is not enabled, and the portfolio reports use the transaction purchase value - however, if original transaction information is defined for a transaction, this information can be set to be shown on the reports by default. No matter which price is used by default, you can always change this selection when creating reports.

title: Transactions
body: Deleting a transaction is not allowed

title: Transactions
body: By enabling this setting, deleting a transaction or a trade order is disabled, i.e. the Delete button in the Transaction or Trade order window is greyed out, and you cannot delete transactions or trade orders manually from the system through the corresponding window. In addition, when enabled, transactions with the status "Deleted" cannot be modified by anyone other than ADMIN users. See also Permissions for usage for preventing deleting transactions for a certain user role with permissions.

title: Transactions
body: Available trade order statuses

title: Transactions
body: Enable the trade order statuses you want to be able to utilize in your trade order flows. The available trade order statuses include Open, Accepted, Executable, Sent to execution, In execution, Partially executed in the market, Executed in the market, Settled in the market, Executed, Cancelled, Rejected, and Expired. The statuses Open and Executed are always selected, since they are utilized by the system in different functions - the other statuses are free for you to choose from, depending on the trade order life cycle you want to maintain.

title: Preference - Yield curves
body: Yield curves are used for valuating contracts and contract-type investments. For details see Steps to set up yield curves for valuating forward cashflows.

title: Curves
body: Yield curve preferences allow you to define individual yield curves in the system. The yield curve is a curve showing several interest rates across different times - yield is known with certainty for a few specific maturity dates, while the other maturities are calculated by interpolation. In FA, the points of the yield curve are defined as securities with different tenors (i.e. time period) and with market data observations containing the valuation information, and the yield curve preferences allow you to form a yield curve from a collection of securities with different tenors.

title: Curves
body: You can set up a yield curve as a list of securities that together form the yield curve, and give additional settings to describe how values between the observations are interpolated or extrapolated:

title: Curves
body: Name

title: Curves
body: Name of your yield curve, used to identify and select the curve on other preferences and views.

title: Curves
body: Securities

title: Curves
body: Security listing tells you which securities have been linked to the yield curve and with what tenors. The linked security and its tenor tell the yield curve where to fetch the points for each time period when building the curve. You can Add security to add new points to your curve - you need at least two interest-rate securities with different maturities for interpolation to work between them. The linked securities should contain the following relevant configurations:

title: Curves
body: Tenor - indicate which time period the linked security's values are associated with. You have a variety of options for days (D), weeks (W), months (M), and years (Y) - make sure the tenor corresponds with the values you are getting for the security. You should only add one security with the same tenor to your yield curve.

title: Curves
body: Market data - Add daily values for your linked securities as market data - These values are used as points of your yield curve. Make sure you get a daily feed for all the linked securities - if an entry is missing from one of the interest rates for one date, the interest rate with that tenor is ignored for that date, and a value is interpolated from other existing interest rates instead.

title: Curves
body: (Multipliers) - if you are getting the points of your yield curve as percentages from your market data feed (e.g. market date entry 2,73 means interest rate 2,73 %), you should set both multipliers to 100.

title: Curves
body: Value type

title: Curves
body: Select from DiscountFactor or ZeroRate. This setting tells the curve what kind of values you are feeding into the curve, i.e. whether the market data observations on your linked securities are discount factors or rates (e.g. interest rates).

title: Curves
body: Day count

title: Curves
body: Used to determine what kind of calculation value is used to represent one year. Select from available day count conventions.

title: Curves
body: Interpolator

title: Curves
body: Select what kind of an algorithm to use when the system needs to calculate new values between existing values.

title: Curves
body: Left extrapolator / Right extrapolator

title: Curves
body: Select what kind of an algorithm to use when the system needs to calculate new values outside of existing values.

title: Curves
body: Once a yield curve has been set up, you can see the curve for different valuation dates in the Yield curves view. To show the curve/point of the curve for a certain date, the system fetches the securities linked to the curve, tenor from the security, and market data observations from the security on a given valuation date to show the curve and its values on a certain date.

title: Preference view
body: Preference view gathers together all application preferences, providing you with an easy way to browse through and manage all your preferences in one place.

title: Preference view
body: You can access your preferences by navigating through the tree on the left. Preferences are grouped under common titles and ordered alphabetically to help you to find them – you can easily open and close the sections with a single click.

title: Preference view
body: You are notified if your changes to the preferences have been successfully saved or if you are unable to delete a preference that is already in use.

title: Fund wizard
body: The Fund wizard lets you set up a fund or edit settings for an existing fund in FA Fund Management app. When you set up a fund in the FA Fund management app, FA creates a fund portfolio with the specified properties in FA Back to store the fund information and manage fund investments.

title: Fund wizard
body: To set up a new fund, click the Add fund button at the top-right of the NAV status view. To view and edit the settings of an existing fund, click the Edit fund button in the Fund details pane.

title: Fund wizard
body: The Fund wizard fields are described below.

title: Basic info tab
body: The Basic info tab contains the basic information about the fund.

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund company*

title: Basic info tab
body: The company the fund is administered by. See Fund company wizard.

title: Basic info tab
body: Language*

title: Basic info tab
body: The language to be used in portfolio reports. You can also see the language of the fund in the contact of the company in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical*

title: Basic info tab
body: Juridical form of the fund company. You can also see the juridical form in the contact of the company in FA Back.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund name.

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund business ID

title: Basic info tab
body: The ID provided by the authorities for your fund. Fund business ID is used for tax reporting purposes. The ID is saved in FA Back. You can find it in the Portfolio window, IDs tab.

title: Basic info tab
body: ID*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique fund ID used to identify the fund and search for funds. You should only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Basic info tab
body: Currency*

title: Basic info tab
body: Fund currency. Once you create a fund, the currency can't be changed.

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method*

title: Basic info tab
body: Valuation method for the fund portfolio:

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Average price with separate items – Valuates portfolio with average price, but keeps track of original purchase dates.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO (combined) – Valuates the portfolio based directly on transactions in the subportfolios.

title: Basic info tab
body: FIFO with adjustments – Uses transaction types that control the market value of the positions with the transaction's trade amount, such as Private Equity transaction types.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Portfolio type. Choose the type that corresponds to the fund portfolio.

title: Cash accounts
body: Cash accounts for the fund.

title: Cash accounts
body: Name*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account name.

title: Cash accounts
body: Currency*

title: Cash accounts
body: Account currency.

title: Cash accounts
body: Account number*

title: Cash accounts
body: The account number, for example, the bank account number.

title: Cash accounts
body: Set as default account

title: Cash accounts
body: Set the account as the default account of the portfolio. All transactions are by default created against this account.

title: Schedules tab
body: The Schedules tab contains schedule settings for calculating NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV for the fund. Schedules let you track your fund's status. For example, you can see if NAV or fees have to be calculated today. You need to fill in the dates only once. After that, dates are updated every time you accept the calculation.

title: Schedules tab
body: The Schedules tab features settings for different workflows. You can set a schedule to calculate:

title: Schedules tab
body: NAV and fees as a part of regular NAV calculation workflow.

title: Schedules tab
body: Fees, in addition to the regular NAV calculation schedule, between the regular NAV calculation dates (to set a schedule for this workflow, click Add separate fee calculation schedule).

title: Schedules tab
body: Performance fee with equalization method (to set a schedule for performance fee equalization, click Add fee crystallization schedule). You can also use the same schedule for fee capitalization if you have chosen it in fee settings on the Fee structure tab.

title: Schedules tab
body: Unofficial NAV for reporting purposes between the scheduled regular NAV calculations (to set a schedule for this workflow, click Add unofficial NAV calculation schedule).

title: Schedules tab
body: To learn more about calculation workflows, see Workflows and NAV statuses.

title: Schedules tab
body: Frequency

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation frequency: daily, weekly, every two weeks, and so on.

title: Schedules tab
body: If you want to make calculations without a preset schedule, choose "No schedule" and select Allow non-scheduled calculations below. This option is available for NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV calculations.

title: Schedules tab
body: Holiday calendar

title: Schedules tab
body: The holiday calendar to take into account in the calculation schedule. If you don't find a suitable holiday calendar from the list, you can create a calendar in FA Back (for details, see Holiday calendar in the FA Back reference).

title: Schedules tab
body: Roll convention

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation schedule based on the day of the month or day of the week. One of the most common roll conventions is "EOM" (end-of-month).

title: Schedules tab
body: You set the calculation frequency to "Every three months" and the first calculation date is on June 30th. The calculation dates will fall on the 30th of each month (September 30th, December 30th, March 30th, and so on). For months with 31 days, the calculation date won't be the last day of the month. If you choose the "End of Month (EOM)" roll convention, the system will recognize that June 30th is the last day of the month, and the calculation dates will fall on the last day of each month (September 30th, December 31st, March 31st, and so on).

title: Schedules tab
body: Business day convention

title: Schedules tab
body: Business day convention determines how to adjust a date if it falls on a non-business day.

title: Schedules tab
body: First date

title: Schedules tab
body: The date for which the calculation is made for the first time.

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous date

title: Schedules tab
body: The date for which the latest NAV or fees were calculated. For the newly created fund, previous NAV date must be the same as the first NAV date.

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculation delay in days

title: Schedules tab
body: The number of days between the NAV or fees date and the calculation date. Enter "0" to calculate NAV or fees on the same date, or choose the number of days to calculate NAV or fees with a delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Calculate next days

title: Schedules tab
body: The button sets the next NAV or fees date and calculation dates according to the information entered above.

title: Schedules tab
body: Next NAV date

title: Schedules tab
body: The next NAV or fees date based on the frequency, holiday calendar conventions and the first NAV or fees date chosen above.

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous calculation date

title: Schedules tab
body: Previous calculation date based on the previous NAV or fees date and calculation delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Next calculation date

title: Schedules tab
body: Next calculation date based on the next NAV or fees date and calculation delay.

title: Schedules tab
body: Allow non-scheduled calculations

title: Schedules tab
body: Allows starting a calculation outside the schedule, when the fund has "No action" status. For example, this can be useful in case you don't calculate scheduled NAV often but there are big movements in fund’s capital that affect the valuation of the fund. The Allow non-scheduled calculations option is available for NAV, fees, and unofficial NAV calculations.

title: Schedules tab
body: Non-scheduled NAV calculation result is shown in the NAV window. The calculation date is shown in the Latest NAV column in the NAV status view.

title: Fee structure tab
body: The Fee structure tab lets you set or edit the fees applied to the whole fund. Fund-level fees are calculated first, in the order you place them in the Fund wizard, followed by the share class fees.

title: Fee structure tab
body: To add fees per share class, use the Share class wizard.

title: Fund fees
body: The Fund fees section lists the fund fees. To add a fee formula, click the Add fee button at the top-right.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula used to calculate the fee and generate fee transaction.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee transaction type

title: Fund fees
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Amount or %

title: Fund fees
body: Fee percentage or amount in the fund currency, depending on the fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Decimals

title: Fund fees
body: The number of decimals used for calculating fees (0 to 10). The "Default" value is 2 decimals.

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category for the fee. The categorization is used in cost analysis and reporting (see View ex-post costs and charges in FA User guide), as well as for creating kickbacks (see Rebate contracts (kickbacks) in FA User guide).

title: Fund fees
body: Additional options

title: Fund fees
body: Additional fee setups.

title: Fund fees
body: Calculate fee per security

title: Fund fees
body: Run the formula multiple times, for each security in the fund investment portfolio. Used, for example, for kickbacks.

title: Fund fees
body: Formula sets its own account

title: Fund fees
body: Create an account for the fee formula. For example, it can be useful with accrued account interest transactions over multiple accounts.

title: Fund fees
body: Include in income distribution

title: Fund fees
body: Include the fee in the income distribution calculation.

title: Fund fees
body: Use crystallization schedule for capitalization

title: Fund fees
body: Capitalize fees automatically on the crystallization date when you accept NAV. The crystallization dates are defined in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab. Fees are capitalized to the account that has the “Fee capitalization” tag. If no account is marked with this tag, fees are capitalized to the default cash account.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: The Alternative fee calculation modes section contains advanced settings that affect fee handling in the NAV calculation. Leave the selections unticked for regular fee handling.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Include fees calculated since the previous NAV calculation date in the current NAV calculation (if fees are calculated separately from NAV)

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Take the fees calculated since previous NAV calculation into account when calculating the current NAV.

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Allocate fees per share class from the beginning of the fund (for example, for private equity funds)

title: Alternative fee calculation modes
body: Calculate fees per share class since the beginning of the fund (not since the latest NAV calculation). To learn more, see NAV calculation.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The Performance fee equalization section contains the fee formula to use if you calculate performance fee and equalize it regularly according to the crystallization schedule. In addition to choosing the fee formula here, you need to define the crystallization schedule in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab, and the fee parameters in the Share class wizard, Fee structure tab.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Select Calculate performance equalization fee with contingent redemption method and fill in the fields to define the fee settings:

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee formula

title: Performance fee equalization

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee transaction type

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen performance fee formula.

title: Fund reporting tab
body: The Fund reporting tab lets you define the settings to produce fund reporting data, including fund KPIs, and store it in the FA Fund Management app (see Fund reporting view for details). Click Enable fund reporting and fill in the fields.

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Reporting schedule

title: Fund reporting tab

title: Fund reporting tab
body: Allocation groups

title: Fund reporting tab

title: Order execution tab

title: Order execution tab

After you set the cut-off time, use decision tables make sure that certain transactions or trade orders that come after the cut-off time don't affect the NAV calculation. To learn more, see Set up cut-off time in FA User guide.

body: For bookkeeping purposes, you can provide transaction types that are used when creating cash transaction for client orders whose settlement date doesn’t follow the default logic.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The NAV reporting tab features options for setting up custom NAV reports and sending NAV reports by email.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: NAV report PDF template

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The path to the PDF template used for building NAV reports. The path to the default template is pre-filled for you. To use a custom template, enter the template path in the field. To learn more about configuring custom reports, see Customize the NAV report (XLSX) in FA Developer guide.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: NAV report XLSX template

title: NAV reporting tab
body: The path to the XSLX template used for building NAV reports. The path to the default template is pre-filled for you. To use a custom template, enter the template path in the field. To learn more about configuring custom reports, see Customize the NAV report (XLSX) in FA Developer guide.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Send report via email

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Enable sending NAV reports by email. You can send NAV reports by email from FA Back (for instructions, see Send documents via email). We recommend that your administrator schedules the report sending in Tools → Administer → Scheduled functions in FA Back. For example, you can have the emails sent out every afternoon on the days when you calculate NAV.

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Recipients

title: NAV reporting tab
body: Emails to send the reports to. Email addresses in this field are automatically added to the "Report via email" list of emails in FA Back, meaning that all other reports that are generated for the fund are sent to this email too.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: The Swing pricing tab lets you define settings for swing pricing. Click Apply swing pricing and fill in the fields.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Official NAV

title: Swing pricing tab
body: A setting to choose how swing adjustment is used in your fund. Choose one of the options:

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Swung NAV - Swing adjustment is included in official NAV. The logic of handling swing adjustment is shown in the table.

title: Swing pricing tab
body: Unswung NAV – Swing adjustment is not included in official NAV. The logic of handling swing adjustment is shown in the table.

title: Swing factor
body: Swing factor is used for adjusting the unit price.

title: Swing factor
body: For swinging up

title: Swing factor
body: The percentage to adjust the unit price if the net inflow of the fund exceeds the threshold.

title: Swing factor
body: For swinging down

title: Swing factor
body: The percentage to adjust the unit price if the net outflow of the fund exceeds the threshold.

title: Thresholds
body: Swing thresholds are the net inflow or net outflow of the fund that triggers the adjustment to the NAV. You can set a threshold in fund currency or as a percentage of the fund's total net asset value on the NAV date.

title: Thresholds
body: For swinging up

title: Thresholds
body: Net inflow that triggers swinging up.

title: Thresholds
body: For swinging down

title: Thresholds
body: Net outflow that triggers swinging down.

title: Income distribution tab
body: The Income distribution tab features settings for keeping track of the fund's accrued income and calculating the tax on it if needed. FA Fund Management app calculates the accrued income based on the bookkeeping postings and records the result into your fund every time you calculate NAV. You can choose to calculate tax on the accrued income at the same time.

title: Income distribution tab
body: After NAV is calculated, the system creates transactions for accrued income and calculated tax. The calculation also allocates accrued income per share class in security market data (Security window, Market data tab in FA Back) while pricing the share classes with NAV.

title: Income distribution tab
body: Click Enable income distribution and fill in the fields.

title: Accrued income
body: Settings to calculate accrued income.

title: Accrued income
body: Accrued income formula

title: Accrued income
body: Fee formula to calculate accrued income. Accrued income is calculated every time you calculate NAV.

title: Accrued income
body: Fee formula can be specified either for the whole fund or for a share class (not for both). Make sure that you don’t have any fee formulas in the Share class wizard, Fee structure tab if you use fund-level rules and the other way round.

title: Accrued income
body: Transaction type

title: Accrued income
body: Type of the transaction generated by the accrued income formula.

title: Accrued income
body: Bookkeeping accounts used to calculate income distributions

title: Accrued income
body: Fields for bookkeeping accounts to track accrued income. When you calculate NAV, FA sums up the balances on the specified bookkeeping accounts on the NAV date. To enter multiple account numbers, separate them with a semicolon. To include only part of the account balance in the calculation, enter a percentage after the account number. For example, "123456=45,5" means that 45,5% of the 123456 account balance is used in the calculation.

title: Accrued income
body: Mark all “Ready” bookkeeping postings from start of the year to the NAV date as “Reported” when NAV is accepted

title: Accrued income
body: Change the status of bookkeeping postings produced by income distribution when the NAV is accepted. In most cases, you need to have this option selected.

title: Accrued tax
body: Settings to calculate tax on accrued income.

title: Accrued tax
body: Calculate tax of the accrued income distribution

title: Accrued tax
body: Option to record tax to be paid on the accrued income. Fill in the tax parameters below.

title: Accrued tax
body: Tax formula

title: Accrued tax
body: Fee formula used to calculate tax on accrued income.

title: Accrued tax
body: Transaction type

title: Accrued tax
body: Type of the transaction generated by the tax formula.

title: Accrued tax
body: Tax percentage

title: Accrued tax
body: Percentage of accrued income to be paid as tax.

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Settings for income distribution breakdown.

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Par value (the first NAV value)

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Par value used to break down cash transactions.

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Par value account

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Income distribution account

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Over/ under value account

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Transaction fees account

title: Breakdown of income distribution
body: Accounts to break down the cash transaction trade amount.

title: Accounting tab
body: The Accounting tab lets you define accounts and rules for generating postings for income distribution (for other income distribution settings, see Income distribution tab .

title: Accounting tab
body: Automated deferral runs before NAV calculation

title: Accounting tab
body: Settings for deferral runs before NAV calculation. You need to run deferrals to generate postings for the income distribution calculation.

title: Accounting tab
body: Choose the deferral type to run and the previous deferral date. If the previous deferral date is empty, the starting date of the fund is used.

title: Accounting tab
body: Accounting rules for income distribution-related postings

title: Accounting tab
body: Accounting rules that are used to generate postings related to income distribution. These rules are specified in the system configuration made by FA consultants. Enter them in the Accounting rules for income distribution-related postings field to change posting status to “Reported” when you accept NAV.

title: Advanced settings tab
body: The Advanced settings tab contains miscellaneous settings for your fund.

title: Unit certificates
body: Setting for unit certificates. To learn more about unit certificates in the FA Fund management app, see the Unit certificate

title: Unit certificates
body: Report template (PDF)

title: Unit certificates
body: The path to the custom Unit certificate template. For example, "/UnitCertificateCustom/Unit certificate".

title: Unit certificates
body: Transaction types

title: Unit certificates
body: Transaction types for the unit certificate to show in the Shareholder registry view. If empty, only the UC type is shown.

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Define how the unit price for newly created share classes with no shareholders is set:

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Select the checkbox to use the previous price of the share class.

title: Pricing of share class without shareholders
body: Leave the checkbox empty to use the price from the share class with a higher priority.

title: Allocation
body: Select the checkbox and choose the allocation groups to update share class allocations based on fund portfolio contents when you accept NAV. Allocations are updated for the configured group(s), based on fund portfolio’s allocations on the NAV date.

title: Fund company wizard
body: The Fund company wizard lets you create a new fund company or edit the settings of an existing fund company in FA Fund Management app. When you create a fund company in the FA Fund management app, FA creates a contact with the specified properties in FA Back to store the fund company information.

title: Fund company wizard
body: To create a new fund company or edit an existing one, click the Fund companies button at the top-right of the NAV status view.

title: Fund company wizard
body: The Fund company wizard fields are described below. The fields under Other company info are hidden by default.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Name*

title: Fund company wizard
body: Fund company name.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Contact ID*

title: Fund company wizard
body: Company contact ID. You should only use numbers and letters (a-z).

title: Fund company wizard
body: Business ID

title: Fund company wizard
body: The ID provided by the authorities for your fund company. The fund company business ID is used for tax reporting purposes. The Business ID is saved in FA Back. You can find it in the Contact window, IDs tab.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Language*

title: Fund company wizard
body: The language to use in reports.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Other company info

title: Fund company wizard
body: Tax country*

title: Fund company wizard
body: The tax country of the fund company.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Juridical form* (default: Company)

title: Fund company wizard
body: The juridical form affects the taxation of certain transactions added to the fund portfolios.

title: Fund company wizard
body: Classification* (default: Professional)

title: Fund company wizard
body: Classification of the fund company.

title: Share class wizard
body: The Share class wizard lets you create, edit or delete a fund share class. When you create a share class in the Fund management app, FA creates a share class security with the specified properties in FA Back.

title: Share class wizard
body: To add a share class, click the button in the Fund details pane.

title: Share class wizard
body: To edit a share class, click the button in the Share class details pane.

title: Share class wizard
body: To delete a share class click Delete in the Share class wizard. You can delete a share class only if it doesn't have any transactions and isn't used in benchmarks.

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class details and NAV calculation settings.

title: Basic info tab
body: Code*

title: Basic info tab
body: A unique code defined for the share class. The code is used to identify the share class security and search for securities in the system. We recommend using numbers and letters (a-z) and avoiding special characters in the security code.

title: Basic info tab
body: ISIN

title: Basic info tab
body: The ISIN code of the share class security.

title: Basic info tab
body: Name*

title: Basic info tab
body: Name of the share class security.

title: Basic info tab
body: Type*

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class security type. Choose the type that is configured for funds in Preferences. If you have standard solution configuration, use Collective investment vehicles type.

title: Basic info tab
body: Holiday calendar*

title: Basic info tab
body: A holiday calendar that determines business days and holidays in the market to set a settlement date for subscriptions and redemptions. Holiday calendar options are configured in Preferences. You can also set the default holiday calendar used for new securities in Preferences.

title: Basic info tab
body: Share class priority

title: Basic info tab
body: The order in which share class NAVs are calculated if there are multiple share classes. The NAV for the share class with the highest priority is calculated first.

title: Basic info tab
body: Decimal count for transaction units

title: Basic info tab
body: Number of decimals used in the units field of the client transactions. If the field is empty, the number of decimals set for the security type is used.

title: Pricing tab
body: Unit price settings:

title: Pricing tab
body: Currency

title: Pricing tab
body: Share class currency – the currency share class units are quoted in.

title: Pricing tab
body: Initial price

title: Pricing tab
body: (Set for a new share class). Initial price of the share class unit. Initial unit price is used for the first NAV calculation. The price you enter is copied to the Market data info tab in the Security window in FA Back.

title: Pricing tab
body: Date of initial price

title: Pricing tab
body: (Set when you create a share class). The date for which the initial unit price is valid.

title: Pricing tab
body: Format

title: Pricing tab
body: Unit price multipliers to use in calculations. For more information about multipliers, see the description of the Basic info tab in the Security window. Choose one of the options:

title: Pricing tab
body: Show price as is – Show the share class unit price without any multipliers.

title: Pricing tab
body: In percentage – Use "100" in both Multiplier fields for the security.

title: Pricing tab
body: Add manually – Enter the multipliers in the fields below.

title: Pricing tab
body: Decimals for share class NAV

title: Pricing tab
body: The number of decimals used in the share class NAV. If the field is empty, NAV is stored with 10 decimals.

title: Fee structure tab
body: The Fee structure tab defines costs and fees applied on the share class level. Share class-level fees are calculated after the fund level fees, in the order you put them in the Share class wizard. Click Add fee and enter the information about the share class fees:

title: Fund fees
body: Fund fees

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula

title: Fund fees
body: Fee formula used to calculate the fee and generate fee transaction.

title: Fund fees
body: Fee transaction type

title: Fund fees
body: Transaction type linked to the chosen fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Amount or %

title: Fund fees
body: Fee percentage or amount in the fund currency, depending on the fee formula.

title: Fund fees
body: Decimals

title: Fund fees
body: The number of decimals used for calculating fees (0 to 10). The “Default” value is 2 decimals.

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category

title: Fund fees
body: Ex-post cost category for the fee. The categorization is used in cost analysis and reporting (see View ex-post costs and charges in FA User guide), as well as for creating kickbacks (see Rebate contracts (kickbacks) in FA User guide).

title: Fund fees
body: Additional options

title: Fund fees
body: Additional fee setups.

title: Fund fees
body: Formula sets its own account

title: Fund fees
body: Set an account for the fee formula. For example, this can be useful with accrued account interest transactions over multiple accounts.

title: Fund fees
body: Include in income distribution

title: Fund fees
body: Include the fee in the income distribution calculation.

title: Fund fees
body: Use crystallization schedule for capitalization

title: Fund fees
body: Capitalize fees automatically on the crystallization date when you accept NAV. The crystallization dates are defined in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab. Fees are capitalized to the account that has “Fee capitalization” tag. If no account is marked with this tag, fees are capitalized to the default cash account.

title: Transaction fees
body: The Transaction fees section contains parameters for subscription and redemption fees and charging them automatically when you calculate NAV. Enter the subscription and redemption fee parameters:

title: Transaction fees
body: Calculate fee for net trade amount-based subscriptions

title: Transaction fees
body: The amount from which the subscription fee is calculated in net trade amount-based trade orders: order trade amount or the sum invested in the fund.

title: Transaction fees
body: Define default transaction fees

title: Transaction fees
body: Settings for subscription and redemption fees calculated automatically and included in the transaction:

title: Transaction fees
body: Cost percentage

title: Transaction fees
body: Fee percentage to calculate the fee amount.

title: Transaction fees
body: To set the fee as a fixed amount per transaction, enter "0" as a cost percentage and then specify the fee amount in the Minimum field.

title: Transaction fees
body: Minimum

title: Transaction fees
body: The minimum fee amount to charge.

title: Transaction fees
body: Currency

title: Transaction fees
body: Fee currency automatically set to the share class currency.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The Performance fee equalization section contains parameters to calculate and equalize performance fee. In addition to choosing the fee parameters here, you need to define the crystallization schedule in the Fund wizard, Schedules tab, and the fee formula in the Fund wizard, Fee structure tab.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee percentage

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Fee percentage to calculate the fee amount.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Hurdle rate

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The minimum NAV increase above HWM starting from which the performance fee is paid.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Day count

title: Performance fee equalization
body: Day count convention to use in performance fee calculation with hurdle rate. If the calculation period is less than a year, the hurdle rate is adjusted proportionally using the day count convention you chose.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: High-water mark

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The initial high water mark (HWM) to use for the performance fee calculation. Usually, HWM is set to the highest NAV value in the share class. On the crystallization date, FA Fund Management compares the share class NAV to the HWM. If NAV is higher than HWM, the HWM value is updated to the current NAV value.

title: Performance fee equalization
body: High-water mark date

title: Performance fee equalization
body: The date on which high-water mark is set.

title: Cash transactions tab
body: Account settings to handle deposits and withdrawals.

title: Cash transactions tab
body: Account number

title: Cash transactions tab
body: A fund portfolio account to record deposits and withdrawals to. If the field is empty, the account in the fund settings or the default account is used.

title: FX hedging tab
body: FX hedging settings:

title: FX hedging tab
body: FX hedge transaction type

title: FX hedging tab
body: Transaction type for accrued FX hedge transaction.

title: FX hedging tab
body: Portfolio

title: FX hedging tab
body: Portfolio that contains the FX forward.

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: NAV report contains details of NAV calculation that you can see in the NAV window tabs. You can download NAV report in the XLSX format in the NAV window (see NAV window for details).

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: The Preview summary section shows the summary of the current NAV calculation.

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: The Share classes section shows NAV calculation by share class (see the Table columns description in Share classes tab). The XLSX report also includes Previous NAV (pf), meaning previous NAV in the portfolio currency, and Previous NAV (sec), meaning previous NAV in the share class currency.

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: The Portfolio section shows portfolio positions (see the Table columns description in Portfolio tab).

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: The Warnings section shows four types of warnings generated as a result of NAV calculation. For details, see the Warnings tab section.

title: NAV report (XLSX)
body: The Limits section shows post-trade limits analysis generated as a result of NAV calculation. You need to set up the limits for your fund in FA Back to get this information displayed in NAV report. For details, see Limit definitions.

title: Dividends view
body: The Dividends view lets you calculate dividends and run a corporate action to create dividend transactions.

title: Dividends view
body: To view the dividend transactions, double-click the dividend from the view.

title: List of dividends
body: The list of dividends shows you the dividend payments for your funds' share classes.

title: List of dividends
body: Fund

title: List of dividends
body: The fund that pays the dividend.

title: List of dividends
body: Share class

title: List of dividends
body: The share class that pays the dividend.

title: List of dividends
body: Currency

title: List of dividends
body: The currency of the share class.

title: List of dividends
body: Dividend per unit

title: List of dividends
body: The dividend to pay per share class unit.

title: List of dividends
body: Status

title: List of dividends
body: Status of the dividend payment:

title: List of dividends
body: Not executed. Dividend is added in the system, with the specified dates and amount per unit. To complete the process, you need to click Execute, specify other dividend properties in the Dividend execution wizard and execute the dividend.

title: List of dividends
body: Executing. Dividend transactions are being created in the background. You can view transactions once the transactions are created and the dividend status is "Executed".

title: List of dividends
body: Executed. Dividend is executed, transactions are created. There can be still unexecuted dividends if you deleted some of the transactions.

title: List of dividends
body: Error. Dividend execution failed. Click Rollback to delete all transactions that were generated and execute the dividend again.

title: List of dividends
body: Declaration date

title: List of dividends
body: The date when the dividend payment is announced.

title: List of dividends
body: Ex-date

title: List of dividends
body: The dividend ex-date. The dividend is calculated based on the number of share class units in the shareholder's portfolio on the morning of the ex-date (the position after the previous day's transactions). This date will become the transaction date of the created dividend transaction. When you calculate NAV on the ex-date, dividend isn't anymore included in NAV.

title: List of dividends
body: Payment date

title: List of dividends
body: The payment date of the dividend, when the dividend is actually paid to the shareholder. Payment date becomes the settlement date of the created dividend transaction.

title: Add dividend
body: To add a dividend payment, click Add dividend at the top-right and fill in the fields. You can proceed to executing the dividend (Save and execute) or save the dividend to execute it later (Save).

title: Execute a dividend
body: The dividend must be executed on the ex-date that you specified when you added it, before the NAV calculation.

title: Execute a dividend
body: To execute a dividend, click the Execute button next to it in the list and fill in the tax and exchange rate information in the Dividend wizard. After you click Execute, FA creates dividend transactions in the shareholders' portfolios in FA Back.

title: Execute a dividend
body: You can then view created transactions by double-clicking the dividend in the Dividends view.

title: Edit and re-execute a dividend
body: You can cancel dividend transactions, for example, if you noticed that some tax rates are incorrect. To do this:

title: Edit and re-execute a dividend
body: Delete the transactions that contain the incorrect data. Double-click the dividend from the list, select the transactions to delete, and click the icon.

title: Edit and re-execute a dividend
body: Click Reconcile next to the dividend in the Dividends view and confirm that you want to execute missing transactions (Execute). The Dividend wizard opens.

title: Edit and re-execute a dividend
body: Correct the dividend parameters (you can only correct tax or exchange rates that are not used in any transactions). Click Execute to complete the correction.

title: Edit and re-execute a dividend
body: (Optional) Make sure that all shareholders received a dividend by clicking Reconcile next to it in the Dividends view. You will get a confirmation message "Dividend transactions are created for all shareholders".

title: Exclude the dividend from the next NAV
body: To exclude the dividend from the next NAV calculation, create a cash transaction in FA Back. Go to the Transactions view and search for all dividend transactions created. Turn on the Calculate totals option to get the total dividend amount. Create a Cash out transaction to take the amount away from the fund NAV.

title: Dividend wizard
body: The Dividend wizard lets you enter dividend details and execute the dividend. To open the Dividend wizard, click Execute next to the unexecuted dividend in the Dividends view.

title: Basic info
body: The Basic info section lets you enter information about the dividend payment, such as dates and amount. For the field descriptions, see Dividends view.

title: Basic info
body: Fund

title: Basic info
body: The fund that pays the dividend.

title: Basic info

title: Basic info

The dividend is calculated based on the number of share class units in the shareholder's portfolio on the morning of the ex-date (the position after the previous day's transactions). This date will become the transaction date of the created dividend transaction. When you calculate NAV on the ex-date, dividend isn't anymore included in NAV.

title: Basic info

title: Basic info

title: Taxes
body: The Taxes section lets you specify the taxes to apply to the dividend. Click to edit the tax rate. The changes you make are applied to tax rates in all FA applications (see Preference - Taxation).

title: Exchange rates
body: The Exchange rates section lets you enter exchange rates to convert dividend's share class currency into the shareholder's portfolio currency if they don't match.

title: Exchange rates
body: The default exchange rates are picked up from FA Back. It is the market price of the currency on the ex-date (or the closest date). You can edit the exchange rates if needed.

title: Execute button
body: To run the dividend, click Execute in the Exchange rates section. You can then view created transactions by double-clicking the dividend in the Dividends view.

title: List of funds pane
body: The list of funds in the center of the screen shows your funds and their share classes in a tree structure. Use it to get an overview of your funds and their NAV calculation status, calculate and accept NAV.

title: NAV status date
body: NAV statuses are shown for the current date and time, displayed above the funds list. If the date and time aren’t current, refresh the page by clicking the refresh icon at the top-right corner to view the recent information.

title: Fund group selection
body: The Fund group dropdown at the top of the fund list lets you choose a fund group to view. This dropdown shows the fund portfolio groups that have a code starting with “FAFUND”. Learn more about setting up portfolio groups in the FA Back reference: Group view.

title: Funds and share classes in the list
body: Fund share classes are shown under each fund in the list. To add a fund, click the Add fund button at the top-right and fill in the fields in the Fund wizard. To add a share class, click in the Fund details pane on the right and fill in the fields in the Share class wizard.

title: Table columns
body: ID

title: Table columns
body: Portfolio ID for funds and Security code for share classes.

title: Table columns
body: Status

title: Table columns
body: NAV calculation status that indicates if you should calculate NAV for the fund today. Lean more about the statuses in the Workflows and NAV statuses section.

title: Table columns
body: If there are any errors, you can see the icon next to the fund status. To view the errors, hover the mouse over the icon. To find out the error details, go to the audit log in the Fund details pane: Fund details pane.

title: Table columns
body: Next NAV

title: Table columns
body: The date for which you should calculate and accept NAV next. NAV date may differ from the calculation date – the date when you should do the calculation.

title: Table columns
body: For example, you might calculate NAV for the last day of the month (for example, 31.1) on the first day of the next month (for example, 1.2). When you log in on 1.2 your fund status would be “pending NAV”, but the next NAV date would show 31.1.

title: Table columns
body: The date switches to the next one in the schedule as soon as you accept the calculated NAV.

title: Table columns

title: Table columns

title: Table columns

title: Table columns
